title: Je suis Emma: Je suis Charlie
content: [caption id="attachment_95618" align="aligncenter" width="400"] Managing Editor Emma Chiu covers her lips with the title of her new column, "Je suis Emma." Photo by Emma Chiu.[/caption] The following piece is the first installation of a new column titled "Je suis Emma." It serves as an introduction to what the column will be about and how it was inspired. “Je suis Charlie.” Millions of tweets, Facebook posts and protest signs have donned these words in response to the terrorist attack on the French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, which resulted in the deaths of 12 people. In the past, the magazine has produced offensive caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad and has openly criticized Islam. Using the phrase “Je suis Charlie” is not an agreement with Charlie Hebdo's statements and images that blatantly disrespect the beliefs of Islam. (It is also not intended to imply that I speak French.) “Je suis Charlie” is a symbol of supporting freedom of the press and showing no fear to those who attempt to stifle that freedom. Unfortunately, we’ve seen too often how tragic events spark protests and strong trends on social media, but after several weeks, or even days, the interest quickly fades — a point eloquently made by fellow Palo Alto High School journalist Kelly Shi in the most recent issue of Verde Magazine. Just look at how 58 percent of Americans supported stricter gun control laws just after the Newtown shootings in 2012, but by October 2014, that support had fallen to 47 percent, according to surveys conducted by Gallup Poll. So, this new column is my long-term commitment to supporting freedom of the press by discussing controversial topics that relate to high school students and expressing my possibly unpopular opinions. Right now, the public has been strongly urging journalists to push the envelope when it comes to controversy and show that we are not afraid to exercise our rights. However, this movement collides with the common journalistic principle that “just because you can say something doesn’t mean you should.” In my opinion, there is a problem in writing with the intent to offend (as Charlie Hebdo seems to have done), but there is still a power in writing with the intent to provoke. What can you expect from this column? Well since the words “high school” and “controversy” are so often seen together, you can expect almost anything. I intend to reveal my unconventional thoughts on people applying to over 20 colleges, worshiping Beyoncé as a goddess and/or watching a “trash” reality show like “The Bachelor.” I want to address hook-up culture, upperclassmen entitlement and stigmas that come from labels. I often like to use statistics but at the same time add a little sass or sarcasm. Some pieces may be more serious or light-hearted than others. One thing I can guarantee though: sugar-coating gets checked at the door. This project will be a column and not a collection of separate opinion pieces for a reason: the phrase “Je suis Emma” will appear in each new column to serve as an ongoing reminder of last week’s overflowing support for freedom of the press, as well as a way to honor those who were killed for exercising their rights. With the title "Je suis Emma," I hope to emphasize that both writing and reading these pieces are in themselves support of that freedom. Je suis Charlie. Je suis Emma.
excerpt: “Je suis Charlie” is not an agreement with Charlie Hebdo's statements and images that blatantly disrespect the beliefs of Islam. (It is also not intended to imply that I speak French.) “Je suis Charlie” is a symbol of supporting freedom of the press and showing no fear to those who attempt to stifle that freedom.
author: Emma Chiu

title: Paly grads to speak at “Listen and Learn”
content:
Palo Alto High School alumni will share their experiences about the college application process and life at college at “Listen and Learn” during tutorial tomorrow in Room 29 (upstairs of the Tower building).

Hosted by the College and Career Center, the talk is open to students of all grades and will consist of a Q&A session and two breakout sessions.

“In the first half hour, I’ll introduce them [the graduates] and ask them some questions, then people can ask follow-up questions,” college advisor Sandra Cernobori said. “After that, there’s going to be a couple break out sessions on two different topics: One is about how course expectations differ from high school to college and the other one is about the transition to college - how to get involved and make the transition smoother.”

According to Cernobori, the purpose of the talk is for students to get first–hand information on the journey from high school to college.

“I think a lot of our Paly grads have some really interesting insights,” Cernobori said. “Not only about the college application process, but what college life is actually like from someone who’s had this preparation.”

The alumni speakers include Jessica Feinberg of Smith College, Sergey Smirnov of NYU Polytechnic, DaVaughn Dillahunty of Coppin State University, Helen Cane of Columbia University and Cobin Dodd of Macalester College.
excerpt: Palo Alto High School alumni will share their experiences about the college search and life at college in “Listen and Learn” during tutorial tomorrow in Room 29.
author: Jeanette Wong

title: Liveblog: 72nd annual Golden Globes

title: Last day to add a class is Friday, Jan. 16
author: Lizzie Chun

title: Preview: Girls’ soccer to kick off league season against Los Altos
content: The Palo Alto High School girls' soccer team (6-0-0) will open its league season with a challenging game against Los Altos High School (1-5-0) at 3:30 p.m. tomorrow at Los Altos High School. Paly ended it pre-season on Monday by winning against Gunn High School in its last non-league game 6-0. The team is hopeful for a win against Los Altos after tying the team 2-2 in its first league game last year. "Los Altos has been a tough team for us in past seasons," assistant coach Eric Seedman said. "Even when we have outplayed them, we've had trouble getting wins." Seedman feels that the team needs to improve its offensive attack and better act on opportunities to score. "The team can lose focus at times, especially when we have a lead in the game," Seedman said. "Some games we have struggled to finish easy chances." According to Seedman, although the Los Altos team returns many quality players from last season, it also welcomes a new coach. Seedman said he is unsure of what to expect based on Los Altos's pre-season.  "They [Los Altos] had an odd selection of pre-season games, with opponents from outside of CCS [Central Coast Section] for the most part, so we do not know how to gauge their results," Seedman said. Paly will enter this game with a strong pre-season with a total of 25 goals in 6 games, according to junior co-captain and defensive midfielder Jacey Pederson. "This pre-season has been the best pre-season we've had as a team all of the years I've been in the program," Pederson said. Pederson is looking forward to the match with confidence. "In the past, we have struggled against Los Altos,"  Pederson said. "But I have faith that this year we can come out strong and get the result [we want]."
excerpt: The Palo Alto High School girls' soccer team (6-0-0) will open its league season with a challenging game against Los Altos High School (1-5-0) at 3:30 p.m. tomorrow at Los Altos High School.
author: Saba Moussavian

title: Recap: Boys’ basketball maintains lead to win first league game
excerpt: Despite a slow finish, the Palo Alto High boys' basketball team (9-2, 0-0) managed to keep its lead, winning its first league game against Fremont High School (6-8, 0-0) with a final score of 58-44.
author: Claire Krugler

title: Slideshow: Boys’ soccer defeat rival Gunn
content: Palo Alto High School boys' soccer team (4-1-2) beat rival Gunn High School (3-4-1) 3-0 in its last preseason match yesterday at home. Senior forward Edward Chen scored the first goal of the game in the first half. In the second half, sophomore midfielder Brian Tracy scored the second goal for Paly, followed soon after by a header goal by junior midfielder Dami Bolarinwa off of a corner kick by senior captain and center midfielder Wesley Woo. “3-0 kind of seems like a blowout, but it was a hard game,” Chen said. “We had huge expectations and I think we did well.” The Vikings will next take on Los Altos in their first league game at 3:30 p.m. Thursday at home. Correction - 9:32 p.m.  Jan. 7 2015 : The originally published league records for Palo Alto High School and Gunn High School, (1-0-2) and (3-1-1), respectively, were incorrect. The article has since been updated to reflect the current standings of each team. [slideshow post_id=80649]
excerpt: Palo Alto High School boys' soccer team (1-0-2) beat rival Gunn High School (3-1-1) 3-0 in its last preseason match 3:30 p.m. yesterday at home.
author: Amy Leung

title: Slideshow: Girls’ soccer shuts out Gunn
content:
The Palo Alto High School girls' soccer team (6-0) shut out cross-town rival Gunn High School (2-2-1), 6-0, in Saturday's game at Gunn.

Paly pulled ahead in the first half with four goals and solidly finished with a final two goals scored in the second half. Midfielder juniors Jacey Pederson and Nika Woodfill both scored two goals and midfielders senior Katie Foug and sophomore Tess Preising scored one each.

The Vikings will next take on Los Altos High School at 3:30 p.m. on Jan. 8 at Los Altos.

[slideshow post_id=80582]
excerpt: The Palo Alto High School girls' soccer team (6-0) shut out cross-town rival Gunn (2-2-1), 6-0, in Saturday's game at Gunn High School.
author: Maddy Jones
